item.title: Defining Technology
item.description: When we invoke the word “technology”, we’re often implicitly referring to electronics. And while that’s one illustration, it’s far from the word’s main meaning.

item.title: Desirable features for automating flashcard creation
item.description: This note collects ideas that LLMs could help implement. From me § To Automate exploring the frontier of knowledge To “lay down signposts” while reading.

item.title: How can LLMs enhance spaced repetition software?
item.description: Spaced repetition software (SRS) is a powerful way to reinforce what we know. But it takes time and energy to create questions to review, sometimes up to 2-3x longer than the consumption of content itself.

item.title: Prompt writing principles for flashcards
item.description: Andy’s original list § Prompts should be: Focused Precise Make clear what the prompt is looking for “poorly written prompts require that you also memorize what the prompt is asking” Consistent Tractable Effortful Encoded thoroughly Attributes / tendencies Similarities and differences Parts and wholes Causes and effects Significance and implications I would add § Concise Encoded from multiple angles Causes Explanations Generate an example Connect / relate ideas Similarities / differences Significance / effects / so-what Revised using Bloom’s Taxonomy Special use cases: § Application prompts Switch question each time Make sure that Unusual Applications by Andy Salience prompts —How to write good prompts A wheel that can be turned though nothing else moves with it, is not a part of the mechanism.

item.title: Technology is Not Just Software
item.description: To define “technology” as information software is a disservice. See Defining Technology. Not only is it definitionally incorrect but it’s conceptually misleading.
